title: The winner of August's $1.6 billion Mega Millions jackpot claims prize in Florida
description: The winning ticket was sold at a Publix supermarket in Neptune Beach, a town along the Atlantic Coast near Jacksonville. The jackpot was the third-largest in U.S. history.

title: McCarthy revives immigration battles in bid to shift shutdown blame from GOP feuds
description: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy still faces a bloc of conservatives who oppose any short term funding bill to avoid a shutdown. He's trying to muscle through a partisan stopgap bill with border security.

title: Kia and Hyundai recall more than 3 million vehicles due to the risk of fire
description: More than 1.6 million Hyundais and 1.7 million Kias are at risk of engine compartment fires. Owners of the affected vehicles are urged to park them outside and away from homes and buildings.

title: Sen. Bob Menendez and his wife plead not guilty in bribery case
description: Menendez has refused to step down as New Jersey's senior senator even amid growing calls from his fellow Democratic senators.

title: This year's COVID vaccine rollout is off to a bumpy start, despite high demand
description: Some people are finding pharmacies still don't have supply of the shots, and others are having insurance coverage troubles. Here's what's going on.

title: In the second GOP debate, expect Ronald Reagan to loom large in name — but not policy
description: Once the conservative leader by which others were measured, former President Ronald Reagan looms large in the Republican Party. But his influence may be waning.

title: This week's harvest moon will be the last supermoon of the year
description: A supermoon occurs when the moon is closest to Earth along its elliptical orbit, which means it can appear larger and brighter to viewers. The last one of the year will be visible Thursday and Friday.

title: Taylor Swift's star power sends Travis Kelce's jersey sales soaring
description: It takes 106 football players to sell out an NFL stadium — or one Taylor Swift. So when the pop superstar was linked to Travis Kelce, fans immediately took action.

title: What happens to health programs if the federal government shuts down?
description: Medicare and Medicaid are mandatory spending programs and that keeps them relatively safe in the early days of the shutdown, but 42% of the Department of Health's staff will be furloughed.

title: A history of nurses: They once had the respect they're now trying to win
description: In Taking Care: The Story of Nursing and its Power to Change the World, author Sarah DiGregorio tells how nurses had great stature centuries ago — and how they got pushed into the background.

title: Commander bites again: Biden's dog has nipped another Secret Service officer
description: President Biden's dog bit several Secret Service agents a total of 10 times between October 2022 and January 2023. On Monday, he bit another officer at the White House.

title: North Korea expels Travis King, U.S. soldier who allegedly sought refuge there
description: Travis King, a 23-year-old U.S. soldier who crossed into North Korea in July, is now in U.S. custody, according to news reports.

title: The U.S. will allow Israelis to enter the country without a visa
description: The decision is part of a deal that requires Israel to end bans and restrictions on Palestinian Americans and other Arab Americans traveling to Israel.

title: Up First briefing: Trump skips GOP debate; FTC sues Amazon; prepare for student loans
description: Trump will skip tonight's GOP presidential primary debate to hold a rally in Detroit. The FTC sues Amazon in a monopoly case. Student loan payments are resuming. Here's how to prepare.

title: What a government shutdown would mean for the U.S. military — and national security
description: Service members would work without pay, and many civil servants are likely to be furloughed. Congress has yet to pass a separate bill to guarantee military pay as it did in previous shutdowns.

title: What would a partial government shutdown mean for the U.S. military?
description: Unless there is progress on spending, a partial government shutdown appears on track to happen Sept. 30. NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks to White House National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby.

title: Trump bets big on Michigan with rally on GOP debate night as UAW strike continues
description: Seven Republicans will join the second GOP debate Wednesday but the front-runner, former President Donald Trump won't be one of them. Instead, Trump will head to Michigan to court autoworkers.

title: On N.Y.'s Staten Island, anti-immigration protests intensify as migrants stream in
description: New York City has been housing migrants in makeshift shelters throughout the city. In some areas, it has led to protests and court challenges.

title: Seven candidates will hit the GOP debate stage as Trump skips the party again
description: The Republican Party has its second debate of the 2024 campaign Wednesday. Notably absent will be former President Donald Trump, who instead will travel to Michigan to talk to autoworkers.

title: They were wrongfully imprisoned 9 years ago. For Yeganeh, the pain is still fresh
description: Journalist Yeganeh Rezaian speaks about her time being imprisoned in Iran with her husband, Jason Rezaian, in 2014 and how that experienced has shaped the rest of her life.

title: 8 loving ways to honor a pet's memory: Write an obit, grow a garden, dedicate a day
description: How do you deal with the heartbreak of losing a beloved pet? Our audience shares creative and inspiring ways to process grief — and celebrate the lives of our animal companions.

title: New Mexico's Republican Party takes the state's congressional map to trial
description: A trial begins Wednesday over New Mexico's congressional map. Unlike some other active fights over redistricting, it's the state's Democratic lawmakers who are accused of crafting illegal districts.

title: Canada's House speaker has stepped down after inviting a Nazi veteran to Parliament
description: Just after Ukrainian President Zelenskyy gave an address in the House of Commons, Canadian lawmakers gave 98-year-old Yaroslav Hunka a standing ovation when the House speaker drew attention to him.

title: The U.S. has suspended some aid to Gabon after the military takeover
description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced a "pause in certain foreign assistance programs" to Gabon pending a review of the circumstances that led to the ouster of the country's former leader.

title: Writers will return to work on Wednesday, after union leadership votes to end strike
description: The 148-day Hollywood writers strike will end just after 12:01 a.m. PT on Wednesday, thanks to a new three-year deal the Writers Guild of America made with major Hollywood studios.

title: A fire at a wedding hall in Iraq kills at least 100 people and injures 150 more
description: There was no immediate official word on the cause of the blaze but initial reports suggested fireworks at the venue may have sparked the fire.
